content: @Vinit Singh and I have been discussing how the keyboard help works for r and R.
image.png
The above image makes it look like R is the hotkey for reply.

Small side note: The lack of proper capitalization in the Hotkey help menu is a bit confusing.
R (or Shift + r) is different than r, but since it's capitalized, Shift + r is what I tried at first.

^ For context.

but R is actually reply to author

image.png
I also somebody talking about the nonexistent E hotkey the other day...

The character is actually e here, not E. (I mean, yes, on my keyboard, I do hit E to produce e.)

image.png

And even though some keyboard capitalize the labels on the keys, it's not a strong convention.

image.png

FWIW almost every keybind option menu I can remember had always used capitals, I guess it’s just assumed that the UI should display only the keys you need to press, and that no presses should be inferred.
I would expect us to treat Capslock On > R differently from Shift + r, implying that its the shift key that's important.

Rohitt Vashishtha said:

I would expect us to treat Capslock On > R differently from Shift + r, implying that its the shift key that's important.

That is pretty much the problem. I think Zulip's focus was on having single key shortcuts, hence the use of capital letters, but that is what makes it a little problematic. Sometimes the same key does vastly different things when the Caps lock is on/off.
A compromise solution here is to just make sure that all pairs like r/R do roughly the same thing and are grouped together in the help.

84     65: {name: 'stream_cycle_backward', message_view_only: true}, // 'A'
 85     67: {name: 'C_deprecated', message_view_only: true}, // 'C'
 86     68: {name: 'stream_cycle_forward', message_view_only: true}, // 'D'
 87     71: {name: 'G_end', message_view_only: true}, // 'G'
 88     74: {name: 'vim_page_down', message_view_only: true}, // 'J'
 89     75: {name: 'vim_page_up', message_view_only: true}, // 'K'
 90     77: {name: 'toggle_mute', message_view_only: true}, // 'M'
 91     80: {name: 'narrow_private', message_view_only: true}, // 'P'
 92     82: {name: 'respond_to_author', message_view_only: true}, // 'R'
 93     83: {name: 'narrow_by_topic', message_view_only: true}, //'S'
 94     86: {name: 'view_selected_stream', message_view_only: false}, //'V'
Or maybe have r and R do the same thing, while the current R is changed to Shift + r.
Some of the above have no twins; some have sensible twins (r/R); some have non-sensible twins (d/D).
If we eliminate the effect of the caps lock key, then it would not matter if the menu had small or capital letters.
If we do it correctly, we wouldn't break things for anyone. I hope no one presses capslock, presses the key and presses capslock again.
That wouldn't do anything to relieve my confusion. When somebody tells me to use e as a hotkey, I'm not looking at my keyboard to figure out how to type a lowercase e.

Actually, this would make it more explicit. We wouldn't say:

s -> Narrow to topic
S -> Narrow to stream

Instead, we'll just say:

s -> Narrow to topic
SHIFT + s -> Narrow to stream

What's the confusion?
If your caps lock was on and you weren't aware of it, that would be a problem.
The reason I picked up on this problem today was because Mateusz Mandera mentioned the R hotkey in the other thread, and I almost thought I had changed the incorrect hotkey.
with a r( =R) and Shift+r combo, that wouldn't be confusing.

JS does know how to distinguish between Shift+r and CapsLock+r. We’re just not reading the key events correctly.

https://w3c.github.io/uievents/tools/key-event-viewer.html
I believe it is actually an intentional decision that we treat them the same. For the same reason we treat them the same when you type in the compose box.

Everybody knows the difference between r and R, and the keyboard mechanics are just an implementation detail. It’s control, alt, command, function, and various Mac keys that don’t even have names that muddy the waters here.
Keyboard shortcuts are different than typing text, so I question that decision. Your browser distinguishes between Ctrl+C and Ctrl+Shift+C the same way whether CapsLock is on or off.
Vim treats caps lock like you are holding down the shift key.
Terminal apps are fundamentally limited from seeing the distinction.
Chord keys are a whole different thing too.
Gmail also distinguishes between R and Shift+R regardless of CapsLock.
I moved some of this discussion to #design > pianos rule
